prior_works.title: Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference (2nd ed.)
prior_works.role: Foundational theory of interventions and instrumental variables
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the formal intervention (do-operator) and instrumental variable framework that this paper leverages to reinterpret outcome-invariant data augmentations as interventions on the treatment mechanism to mitigate hidden confounding.

prior_works.title: Identification of Causal Effects Using Instrumental Variables
prior_works.authors: Joshua D. Angrist, Guido W. Imbens, Donald B. Rubin
prior_works.role: Core IV identification results and excludability assumptions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the identification logic and exclusion restriction for IVs that the paper mirrors by treating augmentation-induced variation as instrument-like perturbations that affect treatment but not the outcome mechanism.

prior_works.title: Causal Inference Using Invariant Prediction: Identification and Confidence Intervals
prior_works.authors: Jonas Peters, Peter Bühlmann, Nicolai Meinshausen
prior_works.role: Invariance principle across environments for causal inference
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the use of environment-invariance of the outcome mechanism as a causal signal, which the paper operationalizes by viewing different augmentations as environments under which the outcome mechanism should remain invariant.

prior_works.title: Invariant Risk Minimization
prior_works.authors: Martin Arjovsky, Léon Bottou, Ishaan Gulrajani, David Lopez-Paz
prior_works.role: Optimization framework enforcing invariance across environments
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Inspires the paper’s regularization perspective by penalizing violations of outcome invariance across augmentation-defined environments to support out-of-intervention generalization.

prior_works.title: Anchor Regression: Heterogeneous Data Meet Causality
prior_works.authors: Dominik Rothenhäusler, Nicolai Meinshausen, Peter Bühlmann, Jonas Peters
prior_works.role: Exogenous-variation-based robustness bridging IVs and distributional shift
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides a formal link between exogenous ‘anchors’ and robustness to distributional shifts that parallels the paper’s use of augmentations as exogenous perturbations of the treatment mechanism while keeping the outcome mechanism stable.

prior_works.title: Deep IV: A Flexible Approach for Counterfactual Prediction
prior_works.authors: Jason Hartford, Greg Lewis, Kevin Leyton-Brown, Matt Taddy
prior_works.role: Machine learning with instrumental variables under unobserved confounding
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates how to perform causal effect estimation with IVs using flexible function approximators, a blueprint the paper adapts conceptually by replacing scarce IVs with outcome-invariant augmentations to induce identifying variation.

prior_works.title: Unsupervised Data Augmentation for Consistency Training
prior_works.authors: Qizhe Xie, Zihang Dai, Eduard Hovy, Minh-Thang Luong, Quoc V. Le
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the practice of enforcing prediction consistency under strong, label-preserving augmentations, which the paper repurposes as an outcome-invariance regularizer aligned with causal identification objectives.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s central idea—using outcome-invariant data augmentation (DA) to enable generalization across interventions and mitigate hidden confounding—sits at the intersection of causal identification and invariance-based learning. Pearl’s causal framework anchors the discussion by formalizing interventions and instrumental variables (IVs), while Angrist–Imbens–Rubin articulate IV identification and excludability; these concepts directly motivate viewing DA as an exogenous perturbation of the treatment mechanism that preserves the outcome mechanism, akin to an instrument. From the invariance side, Peters–Bühlmann–Meinshausen’s Invariant Causal Prediction reframes causal discovery through stability of the conditional outcome across environments, a principle the paper instantiates by treating different augmentations as environments. IRM extends this into an optimization paradigm that penalizes violations of invariance, which informs the paper’s regularization strategy to enforce outcome invariance under DA. Anchor regression further bridges exogenous variation and robustness to distributional shifts; its anchors conceptually parallel augmentations that shift treatment assignment without altering the outcome mechanism, clarifying robustness guarantees. On the estimation side, DeepIV shows how flexible ML models can exploit instrument-induced variation to estimate causal effects under unobserved confounding, providing a methodological template that the paper adapts by substituting scarce real instruments with augmentation-induced variation. Finally, consistency-regularization via label-preserving augmentations (e.g., UDA) contributes the practical machinery to enforce outcome invariance during training. Together, these works directly underpin the paper’s unifying framework that recasts outcome-invariant DA as instrument-like interventions and operationalizes this insight via invariance-regularized learning for causal effect estimation.
